title: 107_s2754
content: The Act may be cited as the "United States Postal Service Commission Act of 2002" and establishes a Commission. The Presidential Commission on the United States Postal Service is established with 11 members appointed by the President, including a chairperson, a non-Federal officer, and a union representative. No member appointed can be a stakeholder, defined as individuals with close ties to the Postal Service. The Presidential Commission on the United States Postal Service consists of 11 members appointed by the President, including a chairperson, a non-Federal officer, and a union representative. Members are not allowed to have ties to the Postal Service or be employees of the Postal Rate Commission. They serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Commission must hold its first meeting within 90 days of all members being appointed, meeting at the call of the chairperson. The Commission shall meet at the call of the chairperson, with a majority of members constituting a quorum for meetings and hearings. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will study the mission and role of the United States Postal Service, its competition with the private sector, monopoly on letter mail, and postal-related activities. It will also examine the best structure for the USPS for financial viability, including restructuring options and human capital issues, as well as infrastructure such as post offices and mail processing centers. The Commission will study the infrastructure, regulatory structure, transparency, security, efficiency, and other relevant issues of the United States Postal Service to ensure its long-term viability and increased efficiency. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with findings, conclusions, and recommendations on the matters studied regarding the United States Postal Service's infrastructure, regulatory structure, transparency, security, and efficiency. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use the United States Postal Services for the purpose of carrying out the Act. SEC. 5. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission are compensated based on their status as government employees or not. Non-government members receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while government members serve without additional compensation. All members are entitled to travel expenses at authorized rates. The Commission appoints an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The chairperson can set their compensation without restrictions. The Commission appoints an executive director and personnel without following civil service laws, with compensation not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The executive director and employees are considered federal employees under specific sections of title 5, United States Code. Members of the Commission are not included in this classification. The Commission can detail Federal Government employees without reimbursement, maintaining their civil service status. The chairperson can also procure temporary services at rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting its report. Authorization of appropriations is granted for the Act.
